question: Question_01_(c)
sols:
For $f(x,y)$ to have a local maximum or minimum at a point $(a,b)$, that
point needs to be a critical point, that is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f_x (a,b) = f_y (a,b) = 0\end{align*}

For the function

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f(x,y) = x^3 y - 8y - 5x\end{align*} we have the partial derivatives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f_x = 3x^2 y - 5 \quad\text{and}\quad f_y = x^3 - 8\end{align*}

To look for critical points, we need to find points which yield a zero
in both partial derivatives. Looking in particular at the partial
derivative with respect to \emph{y} we observe that if

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f_y = 0\end{align*} then

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^3 - 8 = 0\end{align*} and so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x = 2.\end{align*}

Taking this value of $x$ and substituting it into the equation for the
partial derivative with respect to $x$ yields

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
3 \cdot 2^2 y - 5 = 0\end{align*} so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
12y = 5\end{align*} or

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
y=5/12\end{align*}

We find only one critical point,

\begin{align*}(a,b) = \left(2,\frac{5}{12}\right).\end{align*}

Since in order to be a relative maximum or minimum, the point must be a
critical point, we have found that the only point that \textbf{may} be a
maximum or minimum is (2,5/12).

\textbf{Continuing the Problem:}

If we assume the second derivative test is applicable (sometimes it is
inconclusive), we need

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f_{xx}(a,b) f_{yy}(a,b) - f_{xy}^2(a,b) > 0\end{align*} to have a relative maximum
or minimum.

If we compute the second derivatives, we find

\begin{align*}
f_{xx}(x,y) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(3x^2 y - 5) = 6xy\\
f_{yy}(x,y) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(x^3 - 8) = 0\\
f_{xy}(x,y) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(3x^2 y - 5) = 3x^2\end{align*} and so

\begin{align*}
f_{xx}(a,b) &=6 \cdot 2 \cdot \frac{5}{12} = 5\\
f_{yy}(a,b) &= 0\\
f_{xy}(a,b) &= 3 \cdot 2^2 = 12\end{align*}

Thus,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f_{xx}(a,b) f_{yy}(a,b) - f_{xy}^2(a,b) = 0 - 12^2 = -144\end{align*}

Since this is a negative number, this critical point is a saddle point
and so the conclusion is that the critical point is not a relative
maximum or minimum and since there is only one critical point, there are
no relative maxima/minima for $f(x,y)$.
hints: How do we define critical points for functions of two variables?
